results.title: The Australian ballet: opening act 1962-1972
results.creator_credit: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, National Library of Australia and ScreenSound Australia
results.brief_description: It was a fortuitous evening when Harold Holt, then federal treasurer, approached Peggy van Praagh and advised her the he could provide the financial means to establish what would become Australia’s first national ballet company. The season opened in 1962 with a performance of Swan Lake at Her Majesty’s Theatre in Sydney and featured 40 dancers, chiefly comprised from the Borovansky ballet company, that van Praagh took over on the death of its titular founder. The company toured Australia, introducing delighted audiences to the classics, innovative pieces and new choreography including Melbourne Cup, and The Display and Yugen by Sir Robert Helpmann who would later join van Praagh as co-artistic director. Helpmann and van Praag represented two sides of the artistic coin - Helpmann a flamboyant promoter of the ballet without being actively involved in the day to day running, and van Praag, the English teacher and educator who maintained a strong bond between the company and her mother country. Introduced by Barry Kitcher and narrated by Helen Vaughan Roberts, this program presents archival footage of performances, highlights of international guests such as Sonia Arova, Erik Bruhn, Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, original pieces from the 1950s, biographical information about Helpmann and van Praag and profiles Australian artists including Marilyn Rowe and Kelvin Coe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, National Library of Australia and ScreenSound Australia

results.title: Born to build
results.brief_description: Bodybuilding is more than just moving heavy metal. To Alex it is his life. Fascinated as a child with size and strength and an addiction to Marvel comics Alex finally starting pumping iron at the age of 16 and became hooked. Follow his journey in this humourous comic book style presentation as he lifts those weights and pumps that iron to build the perfect body.

results.title: The Australian Ballet - Corroboree
results.brief_description: ‘Corroboree’ is both a record of the world premiere of the famous Australian ballet, and a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the rehearsal, design and preparation that went into the production. Inspired by composer John Antill’s best known work, the ballet was sponsored by the Arts Council of Australia and choreographed by Rex Reid. Performed by the National Theatre Ballet Company and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, ‘Corroboree’ is a striking illustration of some of the ways in which white Australia has imagined and expropriated Australian First Nations cultures.

results.title: The Art of rhyme
results.brief_description:
Ever since a child Mykel has had a fascination for the art of rhyme and a respect for the artistic and creative use of the english language. In this animated piece, he speaks of his dedication to perfecting his art through rap and hip-hop where constant rhyme is no longer a restriction and each syllable and phrase flows into a harmonious melody. “Allowing your mind to be blown away, storming the front of your imagination and pushing it to the limit - that’s the buzz!”
Music by Pabstrakt.

results.title: Touching the timeless
results.creator_credit: Richard Meech, Michael Grant and Biniman Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Millennium: tribal wisdom and the modern world”.
What does it mean to find one’s place in the cosmos? What are the different ways that western societies and tribal cultures seek to elevate their lives from the ordinary world into the extraordinary? In this program, accompany the Huichol people of Mexico on their annual pilgrimage to collect peyote, the food of the gods, and visit the house of a Navajo medicine man who invites the spirits into his world through sand painting, chanting and ‘walking in beauty’. Then follow David Maybury-Lewis into an examination of why modernisation can be viewed as secularisation and what the consequences of this means to western people.

results.title: Millennium: tribal wisdom and the modern world
results.creator_credit: Richard Meech, Michael Grant and Biniman Productions
results.brief_description: The western world’s desire to change other societies to its own image has robbed our modern world of the gifts of other cultures. By exploring the values and different world perspectives that hold many tribal societies together, this ten part series aims to stimulate reflection and to look at what the modern world can learn from tribal societies as we all approach the next millennium. Written and presented by David Maybury-Lewis.

results.title: At the threshold
results.creator_credit: Michael Grant, Richard Meech and Biniman Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Millennium: tribal wisdom and the modern world”.
Has the pursuit of self interest that has driven our society since the 12th Century finally run its course? Explore this possibility in the series finale. Return with David Maybury-Lewis to tribes all over the world to review the primary wisdom’s that tribal people offer to our modernised world. Then travel to central France to explore the most perplexing dilemmas of the western world. heart versus mind, body versus soul, the desires of the individual versus the needs of society. Visit a rural French family whose lifestyle exhibits the positive influences that have been inherited from a tribal past. Understand why our survival as a species may now depend on rediscovering the wisdom’s of our tribal past.

results.title: The Swimmer
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Smith, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Man and His Sport”.
Presents aspects of the sport of swimming in Australia, in particular the physical and psychological preparation of champion Australian swimmers for the 1970 Commonwealth Games. Coaches Forbes Carlile and Don Talbot and swimmers Karen Moras and Diana Rickard are seen at work.

results.title: The Australian AIDS tape
results.creator_credit: Nick Torrens, Sabina Wynn, Health Media and Education Centre and New South Wales. Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: Aimed at the general community and provides factual information about AIDS. What HIV/AIDS is. How HIV is transmitted. How HIV is not transmitted. How to prevent it. What to do if you are worried. Offers a telephone number in each State which people can call for further information. A current affair style approach with animation and graphics is used. It was developed for use by educators but can stand alone as an educational resource if no AIDS educator is available. Presented by Geraldine Doogue.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nick Torrens, Sabina Wynn, Health Media and Education Centre and New South Wales. Dept. of Health

results.title: The Tightrope of power
results.creator_credit: Richard Meech, Michael Grant and Biniman Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Millennium: tribal wisdom and the modern world”.
How do tribal societies maintain social order and harmony without the vast legal and Government institutions that we rely on? This program invites the viewer to contrast the western forms of state to the tribal practice of democracy through consensus. We travel to Canada to witness the struggles of the Objiwa-Cree and Mohawk tribes against the Canadian Federal Government and to understand how their visions of the world can help us refine our definitions of democracy, pluralism and the state.
